action.content:
You are playing a negotiation game in which you have to agree on how to divide a set of items among you and another player.

Rules:
(a) You and the other player are given a set of items. Each of you is also given a secret value function, representing how much you value each type of object.
(b) You exchange messages with the other player to agree on who gets which items. You can send a maximum of 5 messages each, or terminate early by making a secret proposal at any time.
(c) You are each asked to submit a secret proposal indicating the items you want formatted in square brackets as follows: "[Proposal: <number> <object name>, <number> <object name>, <...>]"
(d) If your proposals are complementary, i.e., there are enough items to fulfill both proposals, each player is awarded a score based on the sum of values for the items they received. Otherwise, both of you get zero points.
(e) Your goal is to maximize the score you receive.

Let us start.

The set of available items is:

3 candies, 2 fruits, 1 hat

Your secret value function is:

candy: 2, fruit: 2, hat: 0

IMPORTANT: Your messages, unless it is the secret proposal, are directly transmitted to the other player, so do not include any response to the rules or text announcing your message. To make a secret proposal, use the indicated format. Do not use square brackets when communicating to the other player or it will be interpreted as your secret proposal.
action.label: context

action.content:

The other player's value function isn't given, but since I don't know it, I have to make assumptions. But maybe I can structure my proposal in a way that maximizes my own gain regardless. Since the goal is to get as much as possible, I should propose items that I value highly. 

The rules say that if the proposals are complementary (i.e., there are enough items to fulfill both), then each gets their items. Otherwise, both get zero. So I need to make sure that my proposal and the other's don't overlap in a way that exceeds the available items.

So if I make a secret proposal, that's my final offer, and the other player might do the same. Then, if their proposals are complementary, they get their items. Otherwise, zero.

But since I don't know the other player's value function, I need to make a proposal that is likely to be accepted. Since I value candies and fruits, I should propose those. The hat is worthless to me, so I can offer it to the other player if needed.

So my secret proposal could be to take all the candies and fruits. Let me check: 3 candies and 2 fruits. That's 5 items. The other player's proposal would need to not take any of these. But if they propose something else, like the hat, then it's okay. But if they also propose candies or fruits, then there's a conflict.

Alternatively, maybe I should propose a subset. For example, take 2 candies and 1 fruit. That leaves 1 candy and 1 fruit for the other player. But if the other player also wants those, then it's a conflict. But since I don't know their preferences, maybe I should take as much as possible.

But since I can't know their preferences, maybe the best approach is to propose the items I value most. So my secret proposal would be [Proposal: 3 candies, 2 fruits]. That way, I get all the items I value. If the other player's proposal doesn't take any of these, then we both get our items. If they do, then we both get zero. But since I don't know their proposal, this is a risk. However, given that I can't communicate, maybe this is the best I can do.

Rules:

(b) You exchange messages with the other player to agree on who gets which items. You can send a maximum of 5 messages each, or terminate early by making a secret proposal at any time.
(c) You are each asked to submit a secret proposal indicating the items you want formatted in square brackets as follows: "[Proposal: <number> <object name>, <number> <object name>, <...>]"
(d) If your proposals are complementary, i.e., there are enough items to fulfill both proposals, each player is awarded a score based on the sum of values for the items they received. Otherwise, both of you get zero points.
